Message.Title: Sleeping giant or asleep at the wheel
Message.Msg: It's sad that this board is filled with mostly nut jobs, so I welcome any lucid commentary on below. The most comical thing about the Apple bashing that is going on that the general public thinks Apple is blissfully unaware that they need to continue innovating. I like when the lines start with, "what Apple needs to realize is...". This is the richest, most profitable, most well respected company on earth. The talk of Samsung is comical. South Korea, like China, is well known for their lack of innovation and a strong record of piracy and mediocre quality. And by the way, Apple also happens to be the best retailer on earth. Short at your own peril at this point. I can't buy enough of this stock right now. The one thing I do agree on is that Apple may be a little too quiet right now, coming across almost as cocky. Their customers are shareholders are waiting for some clarity. My guess is that's coming real soon.

Message.Title: AAPL mgmt delusional
Message.Msg: Samsung announcing a new phone this week and AAPL still loves to be hammered. It is either today or below 400. I hope they have a counter strategy. AAPL will face this situation again and again unless they have quicker product lifecycles or knock of the competition quickly by variety and target all kinds of consumer base. TC says that he never sees AAPL as a volume player. WRONG, if you are not a volume player, then you will just be a patent holder while Samsung and Android/GOOG will eat your lunch. Either AAPL spins off a low cost high volume device making company without compromising on quality for IOS experience or TC should partner with Nok/BBRY for certain devices and get IOS on those devices to kick Android and Samsung totally out of the Market. This will give Samsung a hard time on their lower end devices. The IOS market place has a potential to grow exponentially in the near term while AAPL can still focus on the innovation on the device side, You can only charge a premium on hardware for so lang before competition brings down the price and profit. Only volume players make the dough with their better inventory cycles.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: Tablet Web traffic has eclipsed smartphone Web traffic, says Adobe, which is making mobile a big part of its online ad tech push. With tablet growth rates still well above smartphone growth rates, expect this gap to widen. The gap is a mixed blessing for Google : with the iPad's share of tablet traffic much higher than the iPhone's share of smartphone traffic, Google's iPad search revenue-sharing payments to Apple are bound to be steep. But tablet ad prices are higher thanks to superior conversion rates, and could soon approach PC levels.

Message.Msg: Raymond James reports many iPhone suppliers have "recently indicated an expectation of earlier seasonality," and takes it as evidence of a pending refresh. A big drop in shipments is expected for the June quarter, followed by Sep. quarter growth. The big question for Apple is whether an iPhone 5S that keeps a 4" display (as has been reported) will lead to a major sales pickup in the face of growing demand for larger displays, and the upcoming launch of Samsung's Galaxy S IV. However, an early 5S release would suggest an accelerated launch for an iPhone 6 rumored to have a bigger display.

Topic.Title: Truth CNBC "infomercial program" doesn't want you to know:

Message.Msg: Yesterday we covered a patent filing form Microsoft that clearly demonstrated their intentions of copying Apple's Pinch and Zoom feature. Samsung, who is trying everything in their power to invalidate Apple's Pinch & Zoom, is now trying to patent this all-important touchscreen feature as well. A new patent application published last week by the US Patent Office clearly demonstrates this fact and our cover graphic clearly points that out. More importantly, two of their patent claims spell this out. Claim number five states: "The display apparatus of claim 1, wherein the size of the UI is adjusted according to at least one of a pinch-in operation and a pinch-out operation. Their patent claim number twenty-two repeats this under a "method." With published applications from Microsoft and Samsung surfacing at the US Patent Office in the same week claiming that the Pinch & Zoom function is their own original invention is testament to how critical a feature this is for modern day touchscreen devices.

"This case must proceed now," Apple counsel said in a filing, "in order to stop the ongoing sales — and relentless launch — of Samsung's latest infringing devices, which have caused, and every day continue to cause, continuing harm to Apple." This second case covers technologies in newer smartphones such as Samsung's Galaxy S III and Apple's iPhone 5. Apple won a $1.05 billion verdict

Message.Title: Apple’s iPhone 5 Gets Rare Price Drop in Response to BlackBerry Z10 Stealing iPhone Users
Message.Msg: March 7, 2013 by Michael Li The BlackBerry Z10 launched in India on February 27, and in response to strong demand of the new smartphone, the iPhone 5 has undergone a rare price cut. Its price has decreased from Rs 45,500 to Rs 42,990. The new price makes the iPhone 5 cheaper than the Z10, which retails for Rs 43,490. In addition, it is the first time the price of the iPhone has been lowered in India. In Canada, the iPhone 5 has undergone a simultaneous price drop at all three major carriers – Rogers, Bell and Telus. The new price is now $99 with a 3-year contract, which is a price drop of 45% ($80) from the original price of $179. This new price also makes it cheaper than the Z10, which retails for $149 with a contract. In the U.S., where the Z10 is not yet available, the iPhone 5 has not undergone a price cut. At AT&T, the price remains at $199 on a 2-year contract. Apple is a company that rarely competes on price. This price drop reveals the competition that the iPhone 5 has been facing, and the revelation that between 33% to 50% of BlackBerry Z10 buyers are former Android and iPhone users.

Message.Title: Missing Parts and how much they will add to the stock price
Message.Msg: In order of importance: 1- CHina MObile deal $90 a share short term, $500 long term (Yes Cook said China mkt will surpass US) 2- iTV $50 short term, $200 long term (this is no simple internet TV, thus is taking so long, duhhh!!!) 3- iWatch $40 short term, $250 long term (margins will be huge here) 4- INDIA Mobile deal $60 a share short term, $300 long term. Many more things to come but this is just this year, so lets total it up: short term gain from product announcements: $240 it gets us to: $670 sometime in 2013 long term gain, say 3 years when the full effect of new products and markets is baked in: $1680 AND this is all assuming a PE of 10, of course PE is bound to bounce to 15 again as the market sentiment turns VERY POSITIVE, then valuations are just amazing. Bottom line: downside here $20 to $50 bucks, upside: see above. Competition? Sure there is but the world market is big enough to fill everyone's kitty. Buy the stock and forget about it.
